stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on creating 3D assets for the craft-themed Course 14, brainstorming star ideas and level elements like cardboard platforms and a desk lamp light source. He also showcased significant off-stream progress on Course 13, including a new Mirror Mario fight and a live performance test on N64 hardware. Throughout the stream, he discussed his YouTube content strategy, a potential sponsorship deal, and his evolving game design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: Course 14, the 'craft level', is in the asset creation phase. The theme is a world built from craft supplies like cardboard, crayons, plastic cups, and push pins.
Kaze revealed significant off-stream progress on Course 13, which includes a fight against Mirror Mario and unique movement mechanics that Zeina has already play-tested.
development_findings.quote: You fight Mirror Mario by kicking up here. Isn't that cool?

development_findings.summary: Through engine optimizations like importing F3DX3, the performance bottleneck has shifted from the CPU to the RSP. Contributor Sauraen is actively working on RSP code to further improve performance.
development_findings.quote: The N64 CPU no longer is strong compared to the GPU because once you actually optimize the memory throughput, the RSP became the bottleneck, at least on my end.

development_findings.summary: Kaze outlined a phased release strategy, starting with broad compatibility and culminating in a version 1.2 that is designed exclusively for N64 hardware, intentionally using features that may break emulators.
development_findings.quote: We release version 1... And then 1.2 is only N64. Because at that point we have enough emulator compatibility that we can just say, fuck it, we're making an N64 game. And emulators will then technologically have to catch up with the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze tested Course 13 on actual N64 hardware, finding the framerate hovered around 25-30 FPS, and identified that he could easily improve it by reducing the number of cloud objects.
Star concepts for Course 14 include helping a Luigi doodle by drawing a star with a crayon, a platforming section inside a cardboard box, and a red coin area guarded by a 'weasel ball toy'.
A demo of the first course is planned for release within the next two months.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a potential sponsorship with Raid Shadow Legends and plans to subvert it by creating a troll video. He expresses a general disdain for advertising and used ChatGPT to negotiate the deal for the maximum possible payout.
context_findings.quote: Generally, I never take sponsorships unless I can think of a way to like fuck them over.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on his past design philosophy for 'Last Impact', stating he prioritized implementing every idea without filtering for quality or fun, leading to a frustrating game. For this project, his goal is to make everything 'interesting'.
context_findings.quote: When I made Last Impact really, my thought was never can I make this fun. It was always just I have an idea I'll put it in... I didn't want to be lazy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that while some hardcore designers focus purely on mechanics, the average player's experience is defined by the overall presentation, including visuals and audio, which he now prioritizes.
context_findings.quote: The people that normally play games, they really are in it for the visual and audio sugar.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses his personal experience living in Germany versus Canada, expressing frustration with German bureaucracy and taxes. He has been in Canada for three years and is eligible for citizenship next year.
context_findings.quote: I'm just glad I don't live there anymore. Way too many taxes, way too much bureaucratic bullshit. The people are all unfriendly.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of his YouTube channel's potential for financial success and PR, specifically citing the success of 'The Problem with the Grass' video as a template for future content to support his game development.
context_findings.quote: I need to make more videos like that. I could be so rich.

context_findings.summary: Kaze criticizes what he sees as an 'echo chamber' within the SM64 hacking community, where certain design tropes like tedious red coin hunts are accepted despite being unenjoyable for a wider audience.
context_findings.quote: Six out of eight rats is like geek mental illness. It's like I must play Mario 64 hacks and I am miserable when I play them but there is this patch that makes it slightly less miserable for me.

biobak.summary: Biobak optimized a level area (likely Course 13) by removing placeholder trees and replacing them with better, lower-polygon versions, resulting in a 400-polygon reduction.
biobak.quote: Rearmament will increase a little, but so far main area has 400 fewer polis and a shit ton of materials and overall removed.

biobak.summary: Kaze expects Course 13 will improve significantly once Biobak applies his graphical expertise to it.
Biobak is currently working on preparing the demo for the first course of the game.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on the outside area for Course 13, which Kaze is waiting on to fully complete the level.
She play-tested the movement physics in Course 13, giving Kaze confidence that they are intuitive for players.
Zeina is creating concept sketches for the game's overworld, which is planned to be 'Yoshi's fruit islands'.
She suggested 'Koopa Colors' as a potential brand name for the crayons in the craft level.

key_stories.title: The Raid Shadow Legends Sponsorship Negotiation
key_stories.summary: Faced with a sponsorship offer from a company he dislikes, Kaze decided to subvert the process. He used AI to negotiate for the highest pay and plans to deliver a deliberately unhelpful, troll-style sponsored video, embodying his anti-advertisement philosophy.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze received a sponsorship offer from Raid Shadow Legends, a company and advertising model he philosophically opposes, creating a conflict between needing funding and maintaining his principles.
key_stories.process: Instead of rejecting the offer outright, Kaze decided to engage with it on his own terms. He used ChatGPT to write negotiation emails to 'make as much money as possible' and conceived a video format: a one-minute ad followed by four hours of 'every visible wall in Super Mario 64'.
key_stories.outcome: The negotiation is ongoing. If it succeeds, Kaze plans to produce a subversive video that minimally promotes the product while maximizing his creative freedom and trolling the sponsor, turning the sponsorship into content itself.
key_stories.key_quote: Generally, I never take sponsorships unless I can think of a way to like fuck them over.

key_stories.title: Evolution of Kaze's Design Philosophy
key_stories.summary: Kaze contrasts his old 'put every idea in' design philosophy from 'Last Impact' with his current, more mature approach. He realized his old method created a frustrating game and is now focused on making 'Return to Yoshi's Island' feel 'interesting' and polished for the player, not just mechanically complex.
key_stories.challenge: Reflecting on his past work, Kaze identified that his design process for the hack 'Last Impact' led to a game that was creatively dense but often frustrating and not fun to play.
key_stories.process: Kaze contrasted his old mindset of implementing every idea to avoid being 'lazy' with his current approach. He now acknowledges the flaws in his previous work and consciously thinks about game design in terms of player feeling and overall presentation, not just mechanical function.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze now operates with a more mature design philosophy for 'Return to Yoshi's Island', prioritizing making the game 'interesting' and considering the complete player experience, including the 'visual and audio sugar,' not just raw mechanics.
key_stories.key_quote: When I made Last Impact really, my thought was never can I make this fun. It was always just I have an idea I'll put it in.

key_stories.title: Course 13 N64 Performance Test
key_stories.summary: Kaze tested the performance of the complex Course 13 on actual N64 hardware. After observing the framerate dip to 25 FPS, he quickly diagnosed the issue as too many cloud objects and identified a straightforward fix, demonstrating a practical and confident approach to technical problem-solving.
key_stories.challenge: After significant off-stream development, Kaze needed to verify that the visually complex Course 13 would perform adequately on original N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze loaded the in-progress level onto an N64 using a flashcart and monitored the framerate live on stream. When he saw it dip, he analyzed the cause (the density of cloud objects) and articulated a clear plan to optimize it.
key_stories.outcome: The test confirmed the level runs at a playable, albeit borderline, framerate (25-30 FPS). More importantly, Kaze immediately identified a simple and effective solution to improve performance, validating his design and technical approach.
key_stories.key_quote: I can very easily increase the FPS by just reducing the amount of clouds. That would be no issue at all.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that Zeina is working on the exterior of Course 13, Biobak is set to do a graphics pass on it, and Zeina is also sketching the overworld. This suggests a collaborative but potentially siloed workflow.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical lifecycle of a level, from concept to completion?
How are initial level themes and mechanics decided upon?
At what stage do Biobak and Zeina typically get involved with a level Kaze has blocked out?
How do you handle feedback and creative disagreements between the three of you?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated his release plan involves an eventual version 1.2 that will be 'N64-only', forcing emulators to 'catch up' with the game's technology.
questions: What specific N64 features do you plan to leverage that current emulators don't support well?
What is the primary motivation behind this 'emulator-breaking' approach?
Is the goal to push the hardware to its absolute limits, or to create an experience that can only be authentically had on the original console?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Sauraen is working on RSP optimizations and that the game's performance bottleneck has shifted from the CPU to the RSP, which is unusual for SM64 projects.
questions: Could you explain in layman's terms what optimizing the RSP unlocks for the game?
What new visual effects, physics, or gameplay possibilities does this open up that weren't feasible before?
How does this advanced engine work influence your level design choices?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly described the overworld as 'Yoshi's fruit islands' where you explore deeper as you progress, and mentioned Zeina is working on sketches for it.
questions: What is the narrative or thematic concept behind 'Yoshi's fruit islands'?
How will the overworld structure and progression differ from the hub world in the original SM64?
How are Zeina's artistic sketches shaping the functional layout and feel of the overworld?

open_questions.context: Kaze contrasted his current design philosophy with his 'put every idea in' approach for 'Last Impact'. He now aims to make things 'interesting' rather than just 'fun'.
questions: Could you give an example from 'Return to Yoshi's Island' of a design decision that you consider 'interesting' but maybe not traditionally 'fun'?
How do you balance your personal creative drive to make something 'interesting' with the need to make a game that is enjoyable for a broad audience?
Has this shift in philosophy ever led you to cut an idea that you personally loved but knew wouldn't work for the game?
